utterances: (Through Translator) We are here to show that we can build freely.
The land of Israel belongs to the Jewish people.
We are settling here and in other places because it's our right.
Gilad says he was not responsible for the burning of Ahmed Ghanem's olive trees, but he won't discuss it further.
The Israeli Army has just ordered some extremist settlers to leave the West Bank for their alleged involvement in attacks on Palestinian property.

The Israeli authorities have also announced that during the olive harvest, a number of areas of potential friction will be closed to Israelis to protect Palestinian workers, and the government says it will continue to dismantle illegal settlement outposts.
Some in the settler movement are questioning the price tag tactic.
Daniela Weiss says she doesn't think it's the right way forward.
I'm not interested in how to retaliate, what to do to this Arab or what to do to this soldier, and I'm not interested in it, and I do not believe in it.
I believe that sitting in the night on a hilltop with five boys and encouraging them to cling hard to that soil, to that hill, is the number one effort that needs my support.
And to this, I dedicate myself every day, every night, every second of my life.
Other settler groups NPR contacted by phone also distanced themselves from the price tag attacks while acknowledging that they are likely to continue.
Lourdes Garcia-Navarro.
NPR News.
On the Caribbean Island of Trinidad there's an extremist Muslim sect called Jamaat al Muslimeen.
Last month the FBI linked the group to four men accused of plotting to sabotage New York's JFK International Airport.
The group was not charged in the plot but the case has thrown a spotlight on the group's founder, Yasin Abu Bakr.
In Trinidad he is well known and controversial because he led a violent attempted coup there in the 1990s.
NPR's Dina Temple-Raston traveled to Trinidad for this report.
It's the rainy season in Trinidad and young men are taking cover at Jamaat al Muslimeen compound just outside of downtown Port of Spain.
There's an elementary school, a madrassah, and a mosque made of cinder block and corrugated tin.
Abu Bakr's office is at the back, or at least it was until last month when Trinidadian authorities came in with backhoes and dug up the foundation.
Now it is just twisted metal and concrete.
The Trinidad authorities were looking for guns and they found a small cache of weapons and grenades and took them away.
Abu Bakr agreed to talk to NPR in what is his first interview since the FBI accused members of his group of meeting with the JFK plotters.
Here is what he says about the accusations.
No, no, no, no.
As Abu Bakr sees it, this whole deal, people he says he's never met coming to see him, a terrorist plot to attack a New York airport, it's all about entrapment.
He says either the U.S.
government or the authorities in Trinidad were trying to implicate him in terrorism.
(Soundbite of music)
Port of Spain, the capital of Trinidad, looks like a low-slung, gritty version of Miami.
Calypso music pours out of small shop fronts advertising roti and Bake-n-Shark, essentially a chicken fried patty of shark.
It's here in a town best known for steel drums and carnivale that one of the alleged JFK plotters, Abdel Nur, came to meet Bakr.
According to the criminal complaint, Nur was hoping Jamaat would fund the scheme and provide training.

I would have thought if this man had come to me who I don't know from nowhere at all, would have come to me with something as ludicrous as that, I think I would have called the policemen who I knew to lock him up.
I think so.
No, I've seen enough movies.
I've seen enough movies.
This is somebody who wants to set me up.
The criminal complaint stopped short of saying Abu Bakr actually met with Nur.
And the FBI doesn't accuse him of meeting with the plotters.
Instead, the complaint says a high-level person at Jamaat listened to the alleged plan to sabotage fuel pipelines running into JFK and then instructed the men to come back in a few days.
Nothing ever came of it.
Abu Bakr says he wasn't at the mosque when they arrived but they did speak briefly to one of the elders.
Abu Bakr says he wants no part in these kinds of things.
I mean, and why would I have been in something, you know, that is almost in my opinion insane.
I mean, you would think somebody who would attempt to do something, somebody would have to have a massive organization, I mean with all kinds of funds and resources.
This man doesn't even have a car as far as I know.
I look at him, he doesn't even drive a car.
In spite of a long history of serious charges, nothing seems to stick to Abu Bakr.
Law enforcement authorities here say they are too frightened to comment on the record about him because he seems all-powerful.
He has been tried and acquitted for conspiracy to murder, suspected to have a hand in bombings in Port of Spain, and yet he remains largely unscathed.
More recently, he was charged with sedition and incitement for threatening Trinidadian Muslims who wouldn't pay him zagatt, religious contributions to help the poor.
Abu Bakr's ability to do all this with seeming impunity has meant Trinidadians have come to regard him with a strange mixture of fascination and fear.
And I saw him in the courts one day, as a matter of fact, and saw the magistrate actually treating him with tremendous respect and calling him Mr. Abu Bakr, although he was facing a charge.
Jones Madeira was working at the television station when Abu Bakr and his men took it over during a weeklong coup attempt in 1990.
Now he works for the government, in the Ministry of Health, as a spokesman.
He says when anything bad happens in this small island of 1.3 million people, the Jamaat are immediately suspect.
The memories of 1990 will make them a natural reference for anything that speaks to terrorism.
Might not be so at all.
Sixty-five-year-old Abu Bakr's background is full of surprises.
He says he used to work in a production office at the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation's comedy show ""Custard Pie."" He was a policeman in Trinidad for 10 years.
He was reared a Catholic.
And before his conversion, his name was Lennox Philip.
Abu Bakr cuts quite a figure.
He's tall and thin, with skin the color of cafe au lait, and he emits a kind of calm charm that appeals to the Afro-Caribbean converts who follow him.
Again, Madeira...
Alhamdulillah, meaning praise God.
Her family supports her now, as do others in the music scene there.
He walks tall.
He speaks tall.
He performs tall.
And I think that that is something that impresses quite easily the gullible.
The FBI began watching the Jamaat soon after 9/11, out of an abundance of caution.

Law enforcement officials say Abu Bakr doesn't have a lot of control over his followers and many go on to more radical mosques elsewhere on the island or in the Middle East while keeping their ties to him.
That's one reason why the U.S.
Southern Command listed Jamaat al Musleem alongside Peru's Shining Path as a regional threat.
Abu Bakr says his converts, Jamaat's members, don't have the same prejudices and vendettas that some other radical Muslim groups have.
So the concern about their link to terrorism is misplaced.
Well, I think a lot of people lump us with everything that is happening in the world.
I don't think that that is fair.
Officials here and in the U.S.
say Abu Bakr is more like Jack Nicholson's mob boss character in ""The Departed"" than a budding jihadist.
The concern is that someday a group like al-Qaida could make Abu Bakr an offer he can't refuse, so much money he decides that it is worth risking his operation in Trinidad.
When we finish our interview, Abu Bakr draws himself to full height and says, I know you think I'm terrorist, but can I give you a ride home?
Dina Temple-Raston, NPR News, Port of Spain.
And prosecutors are expected to respond this week to a request involving the man who is actually accused of orchestrating the plot to blow up JFK's jet fuel supply.
An attorney last week asked a federal judge to allow a psychological evaluation of that man, Russell Defreitas.
His attorney says Defreitas has, quote, ""limited analytical faculties."" Defreitas has pleaded not guilty to conspiracy charges.
This is MORNING EDITION from NPR News.
I'm Renee Montagne.
The prime minister of Israel is making a move that would allow Palestinians in the occupied West Bank to move more freely.
Ehud Olmert has announced Israel will take down more than two dozen roadblocks there.
In a statement the Israeli leader said Palestinians generally will soon see a significant improvement in their daily lives.
NPR's Linda Gradstein reports.
Removing the roadblocks is one of the series of goodwill gestures Olmert promised Palestinian leader Mahmoud Abbas in a meeting this weekend.
He also said Israel will make it easier for goods to move in and out of the Gaza Strip.
The main crossing point has been closed for weeks at a time and hundreds of tons of Palestinian produce has spoiled while farmers waited for it to open.
In a statement, Olmert said he hopes to, quote, "improve the atmosphere, strengthen moderate forces and distance the civilian population for the cycle of terrorism.
In perhaps the biggest concession of all, Olmert said he would consider releasing several dozen Palestinian prisoners in advance of next weeks Muslim holiday of Eid al-Adha.
Until now, Olmert had been adamant that no Palestinian prisoners would be freed until an Israeli soldier, captured by Hamas gunmen in June, was released.
It's all about strengthening Abbas, who recently announced he will call early Palestinian elections in a direct challenge to the ruling Islamist Hamas movement.
That announcement sparked factional fighting between Hamas and Abbas' Fatah that left at least 10 Palestinians dead.
Palestinians welcome the Israeli decision but said it is only a small step toward improving their lives.
United Nations monitors say there are more than 500 roadblocks and dirt barriers that make it almost impossible to move around even inside the West Bank.
And on the prisoner issue, Palestinians say all 10,000 must be freed if Israel wants to show it's serious about resuming peace talks, which have been stalled for six years.
Israeli officials, for their part, point to continuing rocket fire from Gaza despite an announced ceasefire.
At least five more rockets landed in southern Israel today, one near a power plant in the city of Ashkelon.
Linda Gradstein, NPR News, Jerusalem.
More now on that much remarked on wintry weather in the capital today.
The ice and freezing rain in Washington, D.C.
closed 447 schools in the area.
And this puzzled our new president who has just moved his family in from the Windy City.
My children's school was canceled today because of - what?
Ice.
(Soundbite of laughter)
